docs.lead_paragraph: When patients go to Dr. Stephen Brenner, an internal medicine specialist, for a routine exam, their bills can vary by 45 percent. The uninsured pay the most and patients with insurance plans are charged the least. It is not his doing, said Dr. Brenner, who practices in New Haven. He explains that it is because health insurance companies insist on hefty discounts. ''It's a take it or leave it situation for doctors,'' Dr. Brenner said. But he said he knew that the insured paid much less than their share. For the insured, he said, ''it's almost like getting a BMW or Mercedes at half price.''

headline.main: Medical Fees Are Often Higher For Patients Without Insurance

docs.abstract: Doctors and hospitals say poor and uninsured, once supported by bills paid by wealthy and insured, now pay most for medical care, while insured is pay least; problem stems from practice by insurers of making some hospitals preferred providers, allowing their patients to seek treatment at some institutions en masse if hospitals in return give hefty discounts; hospitals have been competing by offering ever lower prices to insurers, not so much to get business but to avoid losing it; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK MANHATTAN: PRESCRIPTION DRUG INSURANCE -- The city may soon help elderly middle-class residents enroll in a state program to buy prescription drugs at a discount. The program, known as EPIC, is open to those over 65 and requires a deductible. But under a plan outlined yesterday by the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, the city would reimburse one-quarter to one-half of the deductible, providing an annual benefit ranging from $265 for a single person to $428 for a couple. The program requires Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's approval. Eric Lipton (NYT) ALBANY: INFANT HEARING TESTS -- Starting as soon as this summer, every newborn in New York State will be screened for hearing problems. The State Health Department has circulated for public comment an outline of a system that will expand the testing that is now given to only about 10 percent of the 257,000 babies born in the state each year. (AP)

docs.lead_paragraph: Atoosa Rubenstein, the editor in chief of CosmoGirl magazine, sat in the magazine's West 57th Street offices on a March weekday at high noon, a dozen assistant editors gathered before her. The occasion: a CosmoGirl clinic, a kind of ritual indoctrination at which Ms. Rubenstein brings her troops into ''the CosmoGirl zone,'' that specialized state of mind from which they can edit a magazine for today's 14-year-olds, who are, in Ms. Rubenstein's opinion, a far cry from the 14-year-olds of 20 years ago.

headline.main: The Age of Diminishing Innocence; Magazines Shift Focus As Teenage Girls Seem To Be Maturing Sooner

docs.abstract: Many articles in growing number of magazines for teenage girls deal with weighty topics with new level of adult frankness; reveal teenagers' familiarity with more mature topics and more independence among early teenage girls; publishers, spurred mostly by success of Time Inc's Teen People and growing Generation Y population, are rushing to publish more teen magazines; table; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Andrew Slavitt, a California businessman, was running an insurance company a few years ago, so he knew all about the discounts that insurers could get. But when a friend died of cancer, leaving behind $30,000 in bills, he saw a business opportunity. Mr. Slavitt's friend had insurance, but he had received care from doctors and hospitals that were not part of his insurance company's network, so he was charged the highest prices.

headline.main: Medical Discount Cards Attract the Uninsured

docs.abstract: Article on HealthAllies, health care provider network for uninsured and under underinsured set up by Andrew Slavitt, California businessman (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The federal government has notified states that poor women whose abortions would not be covered by Medicaid are also ineligible for government reimbursement for the abortion pill mifepristone, or RU-486. The Health and Human Services Department told state Medicaid directors in a letter dated Friday that RU-486, like abortions, would only be covered when a pregnancy resulted from rape or incest or when a woman's life was in jeopardy.

docs.lead_paragraph: DAVID RICKEY had done it before, and he was about to do it again. ''You know, Maria, I am very bullish about the company,'' Mr. Rickey, the chief executive of Applied Micro Circuits, told Maria Bartiromo, the CNBC anchor, during an interview on March 2. The company had recently warned that its earnings would fall short of its projections, and its stock had fallen 67 percent in six weeks. But when Ms. Bartiromo reminded Mr. Rickey of a dare he made to investors a year earlier, he quickly made it a second time.

headline.main: Executive Pay: A Special Report; Leaving Shareholders in the Dust

docs.abstract: Article on stock transactions of some executives that produced tremendous gains while investors experienced huge losses; focuses on transactions of Applied Micro Circuits chief executive David Rickey, David Peterschmidt of Inktomi and former Priceline executive vice president Timothy Brier; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Richard Dina began working 18 years ago as executive director of Children's House, a group home in Mineola for troubled youngsters, it was fully government funded and Mr. Dina spent his time managing the agency. Today, Mr. Dina is the president of its successor organization, the Family and Children's Association, and most of his time is spent fund-raising. His assistant actually manages the agency, which provides child care, residential programs for teen-agers and drug and alcohol treatment programs. ''If you are constantly worried about paying your bills, it's debilitating after awhile,'' said Mr. Dina, 60. ''There is excitement but a lot of stress because the future is not clear.''

headline.main: Nassau Crisis Infects Social Service Agencies

docs.lead_paragraph: NOT long ago, many good employees who wanted more money needed only to stroll into the boss's office and ask. Even the hint that a valued worker might jump ship in a tight labor market was often enough to prompt a raise, or perhaps other perks, like stock options or a better job title. But that is not nearly as common these days. With the economy slowing, some employers are looking for ways to cut expenses and improve profits by freezing wages, reducing their work forces or streamlining operations. And it is not just struggling dot-coms that are feeling the pinch; corporations like Procter & Gamble, Lucent Technologies and Boeing are also cutting jobs.

headline.main: Personal Business; Profits Are Down. So, Boss, Can I Have That Raise?

docs.abstract: Article on advantages prized workers have in negotiating salaries during tough economic times; suggests some strategies to obtaining pay increase; photo; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I am one of the few who is quite pleased with my managed care company, United Health Care. I have severe emphysema, and my pulmonologist, Dr. Peter Rogol, referred me to Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston to be evaluated for a lung transplant. I contacted United Health Care and they assigned a transplant coordinator to coordinate my care. Although Brigham and Women's was not on their list of accepted hospitals, they immediately agreed that I could go there, and agreed to my four-day inpatient evaluation. This was an immediate agreement, no waiting involved. When the surgeons decided that lung-volume-reduction surgery was an option for me, United Health Care and my coordinator gave immediate consent. This surgery is currently considered ''experimental'' by Medicare, but my insurance company allowed it with no questions. I did have the surgery and a good outcome, and United Health Care was nothing but supportive. I wish more people had as good an experience as I. SUSAN GREENBERG Woodbridge
